Article.ArticleTitle: Spatiotemporally mapping of the relationship between NO<sub>2</sub> pollution and urbanization for a megacity in Southwest China during 2005-2016.

AbstractText: Nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>) significantly contributes to air pollution. Long-term NO<sub>2</sub> exposure is harmful to human health. The NO<sub>2</sub> pollution in China has surpassed developed countries and attracts international attention. To understand the spatial and temporal distributions of NO<sub>2</sub> across Chengdu in Southwest China, a random forest (RF) model was developed based on NO<sub>2</sub> environmental monitoring data, the Ozone Monitoring Instrument (OMI) satellite retrievals, and geographic covariates. The RF model showed good performance with a cross validation R<sup>2</sup> of 0.77, and a root mean square error (RMSE) of 11.0 μg/m<sup>3</sup>. The ground-level NO<sub>2</sub> concentrations of Chengdu for 2005-2016 were predicted using the developed model with the multiyear population weighted NO<sub>2</sub> concentration being 41.7 ± 11.7 μg/m<sup>3</sup>. The predicted NO<sub>2</sub> concentrations exhibited a clear seasonal variation trend with winter being the highest and summer being the lowest. Furthermore, higher NO<sub>2</sub> concentrations in the downtown areas were observed than that in the rural areas indicating the former being attributed to more anthropogenic sources. The population weighted NO<sub>2</sub> concentrations with deseasonlization were relatively high during 2011-2013. The NO<sub>2</sub> concentration increased at a rate of 0.81 μg/m<sup>3</sup>/year before 2011 (43.4 ± 11.2 μg/m<sup>3</sup>) and decreased at a rate of -1.03 μg/m<sup>3</sup>/year after 2013 (44.8 ± 12.8 μg/m<sup>3</sup>).
